questions.text: A patient presents with the following lesions on the genitals. Scrapings from the lesion would show?

choices.text: Cells with clear halo around the nucleus

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Tzanck cells

Explanation:

  • Tzanck cells are multinucleated giant cells seen in herpes simplex virus (HSV) and varicella-zoster virus (VZV) infections.
  • Genital lesions caused by HSV-1 or HSV-2 typically present as painful vesicles that rupture to form ulcers.
  • Tzanck smear from lesion scrapings shows multinucleated giant cells with acantholysis, confirming HSV infection.
  • HSV-1 and HSV-2 cause genital and orolabial herpes, with HSV-2 being more commonly associated with genital lesions.

Clinical Features of Genital Herpes:

  • Painful grouped vesicles on an erythematous base
  • Vesicles rupture to form shallow ulcers
  • Pain, burning, dysuria
  • Recurrent episodes (especially in immunocompromised individuals)

Diagnosis of HSV:

  • Tzanck smear: Shows multinucleated giant cells (Tzanck cells) but cannot differentiate between HSV-1 and HSV-2.
  • PCR: Most sensitive and specific test for HSV.
  • DFA (Direct Fluorescent Antibody test): Detects viral antigens.

Management of HSV:

  • First-line therapy: Oral antivirals (acyclovir, valacyclovir, famciclovir).
  • Supportive care: Pain relief, hydration, avoiding triggers for recurrence.

 

Cells with clear halo around the nucleus (Option B) is incorrect because this refers to koilocytes, which are seen in human papillomavirus (HPV) infections (genital warts).

Molluscum bodies (Option C) is incorrect because these are Henderson-Patterson bodies, seen in molluscum contagiosum. They appear as intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions in affected keratinocytes.

HP bodies (Option D) is incorrect because HP (Hailey-Penrose) bodies are associated with Hailey-Hailey disease, a rare genetic blistering disorder, and are not found in genital lesions.

questions.text: A biopsy of a patient presenting with painful vesicular lesions and superficial erosions in the genital area is shown. What treatment would you initiate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Acyclovir

Explanation:

  • The biopsy image, along with the presence of painful vesicular lesions and superficial erosions in the genital area, is indicative of Genital Herpes, most commonly caused by the Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV). The appropriate treatment for this condition is acyclovir.

Treatment:

First line

  • Acyclovir (topical/oral) (Option A)
  • Hydrocolloid dressing
  • Topical penciclovir

Second line

  • Long-term prophylactic acyclovir

Third line
  • IV acyclovir
  • Penciclovir
  • Foscarnet
  • IV cidofovir
  • Topical imiquimod

Incorrect Options:

Steroids (Option B) are not suitable for treating genital herpes because they suppress the immune response. While steroids can be useful in managing inflammatory or autoimmune conditions, using them during an active viral infection like herpes simplex virus (HSV) can worsen the condition.

Penicillin (Option C) is an antibiotic used primarily to treat bacterial infections, such as syphilis. Syphilis typically presents with a painless ulcer (chancre), in contrast to the painful vesicular lesions and superficial erosions seen in genital herpes.

Azithromycin (Option D) is another antibiotic, commonly used to treat bacterial sexually transmitted infections (STIs) such as chlamydia and, in some cases, gonorrhea. However, like penicillin, azithromycin has no antiviral activity and is ineffective against HSV.

questions.text: A male presents with lesions and a history of unprotected sexual intercourse a few months ago. What is the most appropriate investigation to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Serology

Explanation:

The lesions depicted in the image, along with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse, suggest a diagnosis of Secondary Syphilis, which is best confirmed through serological testing.

  • It is the second stage of syphilis, which occurs if primary syphilis is left untreated.
  • It presents a few weeks to several months after the initial chancre has healed.
  • It is marked by systemic manifestations and can affect multiple organ systems.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Diffuse, non-pruritic rash, often reddish-brown macules or papules, that is polymorphous and non-vesicular.
    • Mucous membrane lesions, such as condylomata lata, appear in moist areas like the oral cavity and genitals and are highly infectious.
    • Oral signs may include mucous patches or snail track ulcers.
    • “Moth-eaten" alopecia: A patchy, non-scarring hair loss.
    • Buschke-Ollendorff sign: Deep tenderness over lesions.
    • Painless generalized lymphadenopathy (especially epitrochlear nodes)l.
    • Systemic symptoms include fever, malaise, and fatigue, with rare cases showing neurological or ocular involvement.
  • Diagnosis: By serological testing: (Option A)
    • Non-Treponemal Tests:
      • RPR (Rapid Plasma Reagin) and VDRL (Venereal Disease Research Laboratory) are used for screening.
      • These tests detect nonspecific antibodies and can be positive in other conditions.
    • Treponemal Tests:
      • FTA-ABS (Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption) confirms the diagnosis by detecting antibodies specific to Treponema pallidum.
  • Treatment:
    • Standard treatment: Benzathine penicillin G.
    • Dosage: 2.4 million units intramuscularly in a single dose.
    • For those allergic to penicillin, alternatives such as doxycycline or tetracycline can be used.
  • Complications: If left untreated, secondary syphilis can progress to the latent stage and eventually tertiary syphilis, which can lead to serious complications, including cardiovascular, neurological, and systemic damage.

Incorrect Options:

Tzanck smear (Option B) is a diagnostic test primarily used for identifying infections caused by Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) and Varicella-Zoster Virus. It involves examining cells scraped from a lesion under a microscope. However, this test has no role in diagnosing syphilis, as it does not detect Treponema pallidum, the bacterium responsible for the disease.

KOH preparation (Option C) is commonly employed to diagnose superficial fungal infections such as dermatophytosis or candidiasis. A sample from the skin, hair, or nails is treated with potassium hydroxide, which dissolves keratin and allows for the visualization of fungal elements under a microscope. Since syphilis is a bacterial infection, this test is irrelevant in its diagnosis.

Biopsy (Option D) is used to evaluate suspicious skin lesions when the diagnosis is unclear, and it can sometimes reveal histopathological features suggestive of syphilis. It is invasive and nonspecific, whereas serological tests are more sensitive, specific, and the preferred method for diagnosing secondary syphilis.

questions.text: A sexually active male presented with warts on his penis as shown below. Similar lesions were present near the anal canal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Condyloma acuminata

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis based on the given presentation is Condyloma acuminata, commonly known as genital warts.
  • Genital warts are caused by certain strains of the human papillomavirus (HPV), which is a sexually transmitted infection.
    • They typically appear as raised, flesh-colored or grayish growths on or around the genitals, including the penis in males.
    • In some cases, they can also be found near the anal canal, as mentioned in the scenario.

Condyloma acuminata (anogenital warts):

  • Benign, moist, soft, pedunculated wart found on the external genitalia and has low malignant potential.
  • Site: They may be found in the genital area such as the penile shaft, scrotum, or labia majora of the vagina, or in the anal area.
  • Appearance: They are generally pink and project out from the surface of the skin. Size may vary; they usually appear small but can merge into large masses.
  • Microscopy:
    • A branching villous structure with connective tissue stroma.
    • Epidermis showing hyperkeratosis and acanthosis (thickening).
    • Cytoplasmic vacuolization of the squamous cells (koilocytosis) is Characteristic.
    • No evidence of dysplasia.

The table below shows the clinical features of HPV and the types responsible for various lesions:

Clinical lesion

Oncogenic potential

HPV types

Plantar warts

Benign

1

Common skin warts

Benign

2, 4, 27, 57

Epidermodysplasia verrucosa

Mostly benign, rarely progresses to malignancy

5, 8, 9, 12, 17

Anogenital warts

Laryngeal papilloma

Intraepithelial neoplasia

Low malignant potential

6, 11

Palmar warts in butchers

Low malignant potential

7

Carcinomas of the cervix & other genital mucosa/larynx/oesophagus

High malignant potential

16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 51, 52, 56, 58, 59, 68

Penile cancer (Option A): Penile cancer refers to the malignant growth of cells in the penis. It may present as changes in the skin, ulcerations, or lumps, but it is distinct from the

appearance of genital warts.

Bowen disease (Option C): Bowen disease is an intraepidermal carcinoma that appears as a red, scaly patch on the skin, typically caused by prolonged exposure to sunlight.

Hemorrhoids (Option D): Hemorrhoids are swollen blood vessels in the anal canal that can cause discomfort, itching, and pain.

questions.text: What advice would you provide to prevent the transmission of active genital warts in a female patient with a history of recurrence, despite her husband not being affected by it?

choices.text: Give continuous prophylaxis to the patient
Give prophylactic antivirals to the husband
Give antivirals whenever active lesions are present
Don’t involve in intercourse when active lesions are present

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Don’t involve in intercourse when active lesions are present

Explanation:

  • Genital warts are caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV) and can be transmitted through sexual contact. When a female patient presents with active genital warts and a history of recurrence, it is important to provide appropriate advice to prevent transmission to her partner.
  • The most effective measure to prevent transmission of genital warts is to avoid sexual intercourse when active lesions are present. This is because the virus is most contagious and easily transmitted when the warts are actively present

Treatment for genital warts involves both individual and partner management

Individual Treatment:

  • Topical Medications: Various topical medications can be prescribed to treat genital warts. These include:
  • Imiquimod cream/Trichloroacetic acid (TCA) or bichloroacetic acid (BCA): These acids are applied directly to the warts to destroy them.
  • Surgical Procedures
  • These procedures include:
    • Cryotherapy
    • Electrocautery
    • Surgical excision

Partner Management:

  • It is important to inform the partner about the presence of genital warts so that they can also seek appropriate medical evaluation and treatment if necessary.
  • It is best to avoid sexual activity, especially during active wart outbreaks, to prevent transmission to the partner.


Incorrect Options:

Give continuous prophylaxis to the patient (Option A): Prophylactic treatments such as topical creams or vaccines are typically used for individuals who have not yet contracted the virus or to prevent future outbreaks.

Give prophylactic antivirals to the husband (Option B): Antiviral medications are primarily used for the treatment of active infections or to reduce the severity and duration of outbreaks, but they do not provide long-term protection against transmission.

Give antivirals whenever active lesions are present (Option C): While antiviral medications can be used to treat active genital warts and reduce the duration of outbreaks, using them solely when active lesions are present is not the most effective approach to prevent transmission.

questions.text: Which of these options does not show symptoms of a maculopapular rash?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Zoster (shingles)

  • Zoster, commonly known as shingles, presents with a different type of rash called a vesicular rash. The rash is characterized by fluid-filled blisters (vesicles) that are localized to a specific area of the body and follow the distribution of a nerve.

A maculopapular rash can be seen in various conditions, including:

  • Rubella (German measles)
  • Measles (Rubeola)
  • Fifth disease (Erythema infectiosum)
  • Roseola (Sixth disease)
  • Drug reactions: Certain medications can cause a maculopapular rash as an adverse reaction.

Incorrect Options:

Rubella (Option B): Rubella infection typically presents with a maculopapular rash that starts on the face and spreads to the rest of the body.

Dengue (Option C): During the febrile phase of dengue fever, patients may develop a maculopapular rash.

Measles (Option D): Measles infection is associated with a maculopapular rash that usually starts on the face and spreads downward to the rest of the body. The rashmay be accompanied by other symptoms such as cough, fever, and conjunctivitis.

questions.text: Which organism is not associated with urethritis in men?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Gardnerella vaginalis

Explanation:

 

Gardnerella vaginalis is primarily associated with bacterial vaginosis (BV) in women and does not commonly cause urethritis in men.

 

Neisseria gonorrhoeae (Option A):

  • A gram-negative diplococcus that causes gonococcal urethritis, characterized by purulent discharge and dysuria.

 

Trichomonas vaginalis (Option B):

  • A flagellated protozoan causing non-gonococcal urethritis, often presenting with mild discharge and dysuria.
  • It is detected by wet mount microscopy or NAAT.

 

Mycoplasma genitalium (Option C):

  • A small, cell wall-lacking bacterium responsible for persistent or recurrent non-gonococcal urethritis.
  • It is difficult to culture and is diagnosed using NAAT.

questions.text: What does the presence of painless sores on the vulval area indicate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Condylomata acuminata

Explanation:

  • The above image shows rough finger-like, cauliflower-like growth over the vulva is suggestive of condyloma accuminata, caused by human papillomavirus (HPV 6 > HPV 11).

Condyloma acuminata (anogenital warts):

  • Benign, moist, soft, pedunculated wart found on the external genitalia and has low malignant potential.
  • Site: They may be found in the genital area such as the penile shaft, scrotum, or labia majora of the vagina, or in the anal area.
  • Appearance: They are generally pink and project out from the surface of the skin. Size may vary; they usually appear small but can merge into large masses.
  • Microscopy:
    • A branching villous structure with connective tissue stroma.
    • Epidermis showing hyperkeratosis and acanthosis (thickening).
    • Cytoplasmic vacuolization of the squamous cells (koilocytosis) is Characteristic.
    • No evidence of dysplasia.

 

The table below shows the clinical features of HPV and the types responsible for various lesions:

Clinical lesion

Oncogenic potential

HPV types

Plantar warts

Benign

1

Common skin warts

Benign

2, 4, 27, 57

Epidermodysplasia verrucosa

Mostly benign, rarely progresses to malignancy

5, 8, 9, 12, 17

Anogenital warts

Laryngeal papilloma

Intraepithelial neoplasia

Low malignant potential

6, 11

Palmar warts in butchers

Low malignant potential

7

Carcinomas of the cervix & other genital mucosa/larynx/oesophagus

High malignant potential

16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 51, 52, 56, 58, 59, 68

 

Genital herpes (HSV-2) (Option A):

  • Presents with painful vesicles and ulcers, not large warty growths.
  • Associated with burning, itching, and systemic symptoms (fever, malaise).

Gonococcal vulvovaginitis (Option C):

  • Presents with purulent vaginal discharge, dysuria, and irritation, not warty lesions.

Condyloma lata (Secondary Syphilis) (Option D):

  • Presents as flat, moist, velvety, painless plaques rather than exophytic growths.
  • Associated with generalized lymphadenopathy and systemic symptoms.

questions.text: A 45-year-old truck driver with a history of multiple sex partners presented to the dermatological department, as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer A - Secondary Syphilis

  • The image shows bilateral, non-pruritic, reddish-brown maculopapular lesions on the palms, characteristic of secondary syphilis.
  • The patient's history of multiple sex partners increases the likelihood of Treponema pallidum infection.
  • Associated systemic signs include lymphadenopathy, fever, and mucous membrane involvement.

Secondary Syphilis

Feature

Secondary Syphilis

Etiology

Treponema pallidum (spirochete)

Transmission

Sexual contact, vertical transmission

Clinical Features

Maculopapular rash on palms/soles, condylomata lata, lymphadenopathy

Systemic Symptoms

Fever, malaise, sore throat

Diagnosis

Serology (VDRL, RPR, FTA-ABS, TPPA)

Treatment

Benzathine penicillin G (single dose IM)

 

 

Lichen Planus (Option B): Incorrect because lichen planus has violaceous, polygonal papules with Wickham striae, not palmoplantar rash.

Scabies (Option C): Incorrect because scabies presents with burrows in interdigital spaces with severe nocturnal pruritus.

Psoriasis (Option D): Incorrect because palmoplantar psoriasis has silvery scales and well-defined plaques rather than a diffuse maculopapular rash.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a young woman who presents with a painless ulcer in the genital region accompanied by pain less swelling of the lymph nodes in the groin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Syphilis

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of a single painless genital ulcer with raised edges and a clean base, accompanied by painless swelling of the inguinal lymph nodes, strongly suggests primary syphilis.
  • Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete bacterium Treponema pallidum. Primary syphilis typically manifests as a chancre, which is a painless ulcer appearing at the site of inoculation. The associated lymphadenopathy is also painless, helping to differentiate syphilis from other sexually transmitted infections.

Treatment of syphilis:

  • Primary, secondary, and early latent syphilis: A single intramuscular injection of benzathine penicillin G 2.4 million units.
  • Late latent syphilis or tertiary syphilis (excluding neurosyphilis): Benzathine penicillin G 2.4 million units IM weekly for 3 weeks.
  • Neurosyphilis: Intravenous aqueous crystalline penicillin G at 18–24 million units daily, divided into doses every 4 hours or by continuous infusion for 10–14 days.

Incorrect Options:

Option A) Chancroid:

  • Chancroid is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi and presents as a painful genital ulcer with irregular edges, often accompanied by tender, suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes).

Option C) Herpes genitalis:

  • Caused by Herpes simplex virus (HSV), it presents with multiple painful vesicles or ulcers on the genital area, often associated with burning or itching sensations.

Option D) Granuloma inguinale:

  • Caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, it presents as beefy red ulcers that bleed easily on touch, with no associated lymphadenopathy. The ulcers are typically painless but have a different appearance than the chancre of syphilis.

questions.text: Bubo is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) LGV

Explanation: A bubo is an enlarged, tender, and suppurative lymph node commonly associated with Lymphogranuloma Venereum (LGV), a sexually transmitted infection caused by Chlamydia trachomatis

Lymphogranuloma venerum (LGV):

  • It is a sexually transmitted disease caused by serovars L1-L3 of Chlamydia trachomatis (M/C strain causing LGV: L2).
  • It occurs in sexually active adults of all ages. It can cause LGV-associated proctitis in homosexuals, associated with HIV and hepatitis C co-infection.
  • The incubation period of LGV is around 3-30 days, and the disease presents in three stages, described in the table below:

Primary

Secondary

Tertiary

3-30 days

Days-weeks

Years after a chronic, untreated infection

Small papule/pustule/
Non-indurated ulcer at the site of inoculation which heals spontaneously with no scarring.
  • Lymphatic involvement of nodes that drain the primary lesion.
  • Classic form: Tender unilateral or bilateral inguinal and/or femoral adenopathy (Groove sign of Greenblatt).
  • The lymph nodes may coalesce to form a bubo or abscesses that may rupture spontaneously with the development of
    Fistulae or sinus tracts.
  • There may be systemic features such as malaise and fever.

Lymphatic obstruction due to chronic inflammation leads to fistula formation, strictures, and disfiguring conditions such as genital elephantiasis and esthiomene, which refers to hypertrophic enlargement with ulceration of the external genitalia.

 

Diagnosis of LGV can be confirmed by the Nucelic Acid Amplification Test (NAAT). Antibody detection by real-time PCR can also be done. Treatment includes:

  • First line: Doxycycline 100mg BD x 21 days.
  • Second line: Erythromycin 500mg 4 times a day x 21 days.
  • Third line: Azithromycin 1g weekly once x 21 days.

 

 

Ulcer

Lymph Node

 

Syphilis - treponema Pallidum

(Option C)

Painless genital ulcer called a chancre

Non-tender and rubbery in consistency.

 

Donovanosis- Klebsiella granulomatis

(Option D)

Painless, beefy red ulcers known as granulomas

Pseudo-bubo (enlarged and tender but occurs due to inflammation and not infection)

Herpes Simplex

(Option B)

Grouped vesicles or shallow erosions

Multiple, enlarged and inflamed.

Lymphogranuloma Venerum

(Chlamydia)

Solitary and painless.
  • Swollen, inflamed, and fluctuant lymph nodes containing purulent material.
  • Palpable groove or furrow that may be felt in the inguinal region due to the enlargement and fusion of the inguinal lymph nodes. (Groove of Greenlat)

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the OPD with painful genital ulcers along with painful bubos. And he had a history of multiple sexual partners. Which of the following is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Chancroid

Explanation:

The patient's presentation of multiple painful genital ulcers with painful inguinal lymphadenopathy is highly suggestive of chancroid, which is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

Chancroid:

  • Caused by Haemophilus ducreyi manifests as multiple ulcers in the genital area, characterized by their non-indurated nature, undermined edges, greyish slough, and tendency to bleed on touch.
  • Individuals with chancroid may develop unilateral, painful lymphadenopathy.
  • The suppurative lymphadenopathy observed in chancroid is termed bubo.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Gram staining reveals Gram-negative bacilli arranged in chains, often referred to as "railway tracks" or "school of fish" appearance.
    • Culturing specimens on Mueller Hinton Agar supplemented with chocolate horse blood aids in the identification of Haemophilus ducreyi.
  • Treatment:
    • Azithromycin is administered orally in a single dose of 1 gram
    • OR intramuscular injection of Ceftriaxone at a dosage of 250 mg (single dose)

 

Ulcer

Lymph Node

 

Syphilis - treponema Pallidum

(Option D)

Painless genital ulcer called a chancre

Non-tender and rubbery in consistency.

 

Donovanosis- Klebsiella granulomatis

(Option B)

Painless, beefy red ulcers known as granulomas

Pseudo-bubo (enlarged and tender but occurs due to inflammation and not infection)

Herpes Simplex

(Option C)

Grouped vesicles or shallow erosions

Multiple, enlarged and inflamed.

Lymphogranuloma Venerum

(Chlamydia)

Solitary and painless.
  • Swollen, inflamed, and fluctuant lymph nodes containing purulent material.
  • Palpable groove or furrow that may be felt in the inguinal region due to the enlargement and fusion of the inguinal lymph nodes. (Groove of Greenlat)

questions.text: A truck driver reports multiple painful genital ulcers on his scrotum following unprotected sexual intercourse, accompanied by painful lymph nodes. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Chancroid

Explanation:

The patient's presentation of multiple painful genital ulcers with painful inguinal lymphadenopathy is highly suggestive of chancroid, which is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

Chancroid:

  • Caused by Haemophilus ducreyi manifests as multiple ulcers in the genital area, characterized by their non-indurated nature, undermined edges, greyish slough, and tendency to bleed on touch.
  • Individuals with chancroid may develop unilateral, painful lymphadenopathy.
  • The suppurative lymphadenopathy observed in chancroid is termed bubo.
  • Diagnosis
    • Gram staining reveals Gram-negative bacilli arranged in chains, often referred to as "railway tracks" or "school of fish" appearance.
    • Culturing specimens on Mueller Hinton Agar supplemented with chocolate horse blood aids in the identification of Haemophilus ducreyi.
  • Treatment.
    • Azithromycin is administered orally in a single dose of 1 gram
    • OR intramuscular injection of Ceftriaxone at a dosage of 250 mg (single dose)

 

 

 

Ulcer

Lymph Node

 

Syphilis - treponema Pallidum

(Option A)

Painless genital ulcer called a chancre

Non-tender and rubbery in consistency.

 

Donovanosis- Klebsiella granulomatis

(Option C)

Painless, beefy red ulcers known as granulomas

Pseudo-bubo (enlarged and tender but occurs due to inflammation and not infection)

Herpes Simplex

(Option D)

Grouped vesicles or shallow erosions

Multiple, enlarged and inflamed.

Lymphogranuloma Venerum

(Chlamydia)

Solitary and painless.
  • Swollen, inflamed, and fluctuant lymph nodes containing purulent material.
  • Palpable groove or furrow that may be felt in the inguinal region due to the enlargement and fusion of the inguinal lymph nodes. (Groove of Greenlat)

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with a history of flat lesions near the anal canal, rashes on the body, and hair loss that follows a particular pattern, as shown in the image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Secondary syphilis:

  • The flat lesions near the anal canal are likely condyloma lata, which are broad, flat; moist papules and the moth-eaten alopecia given in the image, along with rashes, are suggestive of secondary syphilis.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are incorrect, as explained above.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with a painful red granular lesion on the vulva accompanied by bilateral lymphadenopathy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Chancroid

 

Explanation:

 

A painful red granular lesion on the vulva accompanied by bilateral lymphadenopathy in a sexually active adult is highly suggestive of chancroid, a sexually transmitted infection caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

 

Feature Chancroid
Causative organism Haemophilus ducreyi
Incubation period 3–10 days
Ulcer Painful, non-indurated, soft ulcer with irregular borders and granular base
Number of ulcers Often multiple
Lymphadenopathy Painful, unilateral or bilateral, may form buboes (fluctuant lymph nodes)
Base of ulcer Necrotic, purulent, bleeds on contact
Tenderness Marked

 

Neisseria Gonorrhoeae Infection (Option B): Causes urethritis, cervicitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), but not painful genital ulcers.

 

Granuloma Inguinale (Donovanosis) (Option C): Caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. Presents with painless, beefy-red ulcers that slowly enlarge and lack lymphadenopathy. Donovan bodies seen on microscopy.

 

Lymphogranuloma Venereum (LGV) (Option D): Caused by Chlamydia trachomatis (L1-L3 serotypes). Typically presents with small, painless ulcers followed by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes), which can lead to groove sign (inguinal ligament indentation).

questions.text: The following lesion is seen in a 25 year old man who came to a primary health center 5 days after he had unprotected sexual intercourse. On palpation the ulcers were painful. Suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy was present on the right side. The patient has no previous history of drug allergy. Which kit will be used for the management of this particular sexually transmitted disease ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Kit 3/white: 

  •  Kit 3/white: This kit is the correct choice for the management of the presented sexually transmitted disease. The details provided in the question, such as the presence of painful ulcers and suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy, suggest a possible diagnosis of chancroid.
  • Chancroid is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi. Treatment typically involves antibiotic therapy, and Kit 3/white is the appropriate kit for managing this condition.

 

 

Incorrect Options: 

  • Option A, B & D are incorrect.

questions.text: A 22 year old college going student has a history of sexual exposure with commercial sex worker, he now presents with painful genital lesions and lymphadenopathy in the right inguinal region as given below. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Chancroid:

  • Chancroid is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacteria Haemophilus ducreyi. It is characterized by the development of painful genital ulcers and regional lymphadenopathy. The painful ulcers are typically soft, irregular, and may have a necrotic base. Inguinal lymphadenopathy, particularly in one side (unilateral), is a common feature of chancroid.

 

Incorrect options:

Option A - Syphilis: Syphilis typically presents with painless genital ulcers known as chancres. Unlike chancroid, syphilis ulcers are usually firm, well-defined, and non-tender.

Option C - LGV (Lymphogranuloma venereum): LGV primarily affects the lymphatic system and can lead to swelling of lymph nodes in the groin region. However, the genital ulcers seen in chancroid are not a characteristic feature of LGV.

Option D - Donovanosis (Granuloma inguinale): Donovanosis typically presents with painless, beefy red nodules or ulcers in the genital area. Unlike chancroid, donovanosis lesions are typically painless and do not cause significant lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: A young female presented with vaginal itching and green frothy genital discharge. Strawberry vagina is seen on examination. What will be the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Metronidazole :

  • Metronidazole is the drug of choice for the treatment of trichomoniasis. It is an antibiotic with specific activity against anaerobic organisms, including Trichomonas vaginalis.
  • Treatment with metronidazole is administered as a 2 gm single oral dose.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Doxycycline: Doxycycline is more often used to treat sexually transmitted infections such as chlamydia or certain types of bacterial vaginosis.

Option B - Oral fluconazole: Oral fluconazole is an antifungal medication used to treat fungal infections, including vaginal yeast infections.

Option D - Azithromycin: Azithromycin is not the recommended first-line treatment for the specific condition described in the scenario.

questions.text: Which of the following manifestations is absent in individuals with congenital syphilis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Genital ulcers:

  • Genital ulcers are not typically seen in congenital syphilis.
  • Congenital syphilis refers to the transmission of syphilis from an infected mother to her fetus during pregnancy. It can lead to various manifestations in the newborn.

 

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Higoumenakis sign: Enlargement of the sternal end of the clavicle as a sign of late congenital syphilis

Option B - Hutchinson teeth: Hutchinson teeth are notched, peg-shaped teeth with a characteristic screwdriver-like appearance.

Option D - Buneo's Triad: Buneo's Triad, also known as Wimberger's triad, consists of interstitial keratitis (inflammation of the cornea), eighth nerve deafness, and Hutchinson teeth. It is a classic presentation of congenital syphilis.
